document_title: Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space Proliferate and Generate Young Neurons
summary_full: This study investigated the behavior of human neural stem cells (NSCs) in the space environment aboard the International Space Station (ISS) for 39.3 days. The NSCs were found to proliferate and maintain expression of key NSC markers. Compared to ground controls, space-flown NSCs exhibited higher oxygen consumption and glycolysis, indicating an increased metabolic state. Upon return to Earth, these cells retained their ability to differentiate into young neurons. Electrophysiological recordings of these space-derived neurons revealed immature membrane properties, including small capacitance and high input resistance, with only incipient action potentials and no detectable spontaneous synaptic events, suggesting an immature neuronal status despite complex morphology. The increased energy requirement of NSCs in space is highlighted as a critical area for future research to mitigate health risks during long-duration space missions.
key_findings: Human neural stem cells (NSCs) proliferate in the space microgravity environment.
Space-flown NSCs maintain expression of key NSC markers (PSA-NCAM, nestin).
NSCs exposed to space exhibited higher oxygen consumption and glycolysis compared to ground controls.
NSCs flown in space retained their ability to differentiate into neurons.
Neurons derived from space-flown NSCs showed immature electrophysiological properties.
future_research_fields: Investigating the origin of increased energy requirements in neural stem cells under microgravity.
Developing countermeasures to minimize health risks associated with long-duration spaceflight for astronauts.
Exploring the potential of microgravity for increasing neural cell numbers for cell replacement therapies on Earth.
Further characterization of the maturation process of space-derived neurons.
Comparing the effects of simulated microgravity versus actual space microgravity on neural stem cells.

conclusions: Human neural stem cells can proliferate in space, maintain their stemness, and differentiate into immature neurons. They exhibit an increased metabolic rate in microgravity. Understanding the energetic demands of these cells in space is crucial for astronaut health and has potential applications for neurodegenerative disease therapies on Earth.
impact_statement: This research provides insights into neural stem cell behavior in space, crucial for astronaut health, and suggests microgravity as a potential tool for regenerative medicine on Earth.
